column4: you haqve a firewall of file sharing not working on the other side
its weird, I can access the windows shares via typing in the IP manually, but not my own. any ideas
what do you mean not your own?
you're trying to browse Samba shares on your local Ubuntu machine?
yes, my own samba shares.
have you bothered setting up SMB passwords?
yes I have
do you have a firewall running?
no
also make sure that samba is actually running "pgrep -v smbd" and "pgrep -l nmbd" should both return process numbers
yes, they return process numbers.
the full error is here: http://pastebin.com/m82e1355
what does "smbclient -L localhost" give you
I'm assuming you've set an smb password for the user you're currently using
sorry, I'm back now.
yes, I've set it up. and smbclient -L localhost times out
I've changed my hostname. it gives this error when I change 'localhost' to my host name: Error connecting to 127.0.0.1 (Connection refused)
sounds like a firewall thing, like the port is somehow blocked, make sure "sudo iptables-save" doesn't return anything please
it does return something. That something is here: http://pastebin.com/m426bbedf
ok. that looks fine (everything is set to accept)
what do you mean you've changed your hostname?
so its not peddy@localhost or w/e but peddy@moonshine (name of pc)
could this problem be with my router?
where did you change it? did you bother rebooting afterwards? as long as we're using "localhost" or 127.0.0.1 in our commands, the router has nothing to do with it
do you think I should enter my machine's name in the WINS server settings on my router? and I changed it a very long time ago (so yes, it has rebooted)
well, my machines IP address
I'm really glad that you're helping me, btw
the name or address will be important when we try to connect from other machines, lets succeed in connecting locally 1st
but lets do a little sanity check, what does "host localhost" give you
localhost has address 208.67.219.132
well, you have some kind of a mess there, how exactly did you change your hostname?
I edited /etc/hostname
the aforementioned IP is that of OpenDNS. any ideas?
paste your /etc/hosts file
127.0.0.1 moonshine
well, that ain't right; have you changed that file?
not that I'm aware of; can you help me to change it back?
does your machine have a static address or DHCP-assigned?
the 1st line should be  127.0.0.1 localhost
I think so, its always 192.168.1.3
but did you set it statically or does it get it from the router?
I get it from the router
the 2nd line should be 127.0.1.1 moonshine
after you make the change "host localhost" should give you 127.0.0.1
do I have to restart any services?
I don't think so
still giving me the same. did you mean to say 127.0.1.1 instead of 127.0.0.1 like in the first line?
its still giving the same error as before
I said 127.0.1.1 for the 2nd line and I meant it
ok, same error. in /etc/nsswitch.conf, is this part like it should be? hosts: files wins dns
in the right order*
I rather it be "files dns wins" but it doesn't really mater as long as "files" is first
but does "host localhost"  give you 127.0.0.1? we really need to get that sorted out first because if its not thing will break
any ideas about it not reading /etc/hosts, though?
nope, it does not give 127.0.0.1 I think this guy has the same issue http://ubuntuforums.org/archive/index.php/t-592071.html
oh w8, yeah out dns 1st... forgot, "host" is a DNS-only command
what does "getent hosts localhost" give you, where does "ping localhost" go?
make it "files dns wins" in /ets/nsswitch.conf
1st one: 127.0.0.1       localhost 2nd one: PING localhost (127.0.0.1) 56(84) bytes of data.
ok. looks better. now check in "smbclient -L localhost" work for you
Error connecting to 127.0.0.1 (Connection refused)
I tried restarting samba, it gives me this: start-stop-daemon: warning: failed to kill 8436: No such process
hmm... it might have not been running after all... re-try smbclient
ok, it gives me shares now.
weird that the pgrep command we've run before found processes
a list of shares. also, in places>network there is a weird file called smb-workgroup-MyFiles

when I try to open it, it says The filename "smb-workgroup-MyFiles" indicates that this file is of type "x-directory/smb-share". The contents of the file indicate that the file is of type "desktop configuration file" etc.
weird. was the last time you've started gnome before or after you've changed the hostname?
no, I renamed it about half a year ago.
what should be in /etc/resolv.conf?
and you've been running with a broken /etc/hosts since then? I'm surprised you could even start X...
you shouldn't mess with it because you're using DHCP
have you read this? http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=592071
It doesn't matter, the configuration discussed there is of a server running its own DNS, its unrelated to your setup
oh, ok
anyway Samba works for you now doesn't it?
nope
but you've told me you see shares when you do "smbclient -L localhost"
only my own ones, and I still can't access them from places>network.
what exatly are you trying to do, have your machine read shares from other machines or the other way around?\
I got places>network>windows network>workgroup and it says: sorry, couldn't display the contents of windows network:workgroup.
I'm trying to access my own shares
whais the name of the workgroup you've setup in /etc/smb.conf ?
'workgroup'
also since we've changed /ets/hosts and the "localhost" mapping this may be a goot point to restart, many thing may work differently after that, and I need to go for a while...
whoa, I can access both computers now. I think this problem is intermittent, I could access both of them before, then couldn't, now I can.
reboot, see if it gets better, otherwise this may be some kind of a network problem (is it wireless?) ?
I will restart, and get back to you. Thank you incredibly for all the stuff that you've done.
wireless network, yes
hmm, reception problems maybe, but see how it behaves after a clean boot 1st
ok, all seems to be working now, but the Window computer does not appear in places>network. I can do the smbclient command to its IP, (but not its hostname). Any ideas?
the smbclient command gives: session request to 192.168.1.2 failed (Called name not present), as well as a list of the Windows shares
you there?
